member.name: T:System.Net.NetworkAccess
member.summary: Specifies network access permissions.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkAccess.Accept
member.summary: Indicates that the application is allowed to accept connections from the Internet on a local resource. Notice that this is a protection for the local host that uses Accept to grant access to a local resource (address/port). At the time a socket tries to bind to this local resource a permission check is performed to see if an Accept exists on that resource.

member.name: F:System.Net.NetworkAccess.Connect
member.summary: Indicates that the application is allowed to connect to specific Internet resources. Notice that, in the case of remote host resource, no check is performed to see that Connect permissions exist. This is because the port of a connecting remote host is unknown and not suitable permissions can be built in advance. It is the application responsibility to check the permissions of the remote host trying to connect to a listening socket.

member.summary: Access to append material to a file or directory. access includes the ability to create a new file or directory. To create files, code must also be granted both and either or access.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.FileIOPermissionAccess.PathDiscovery
member.summary: Access to the information in the path itself. This helps protect sensitive information in the path, such as user names, as well as information about the directory structure revealed in the path. This value does not grant access to files or folders represented by the path. For performance reasons, should only be granted to directories, not to files. For example, permission should be granted to paths such as C:\test and C:\test\\, not C:\test\example.txt.

member.name: T:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment
member.summary: Specifies the permitted use of isolated storage.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.AdministerIsolatedStorageByUser
member.summary: Unlimited administration ability for the user store. Allows browsing and deletion of the entire user store, but not read access other than the user's own domain/assembly identity.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.ApplicationIsolationByMachine
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by computer and then by application. This provides a data store for the application that is accessible in any domain context. The per-application data compartment requires additional trust because it potentially provides a "tunnel" between applications that could compromise the data isolation of applications in particular Web sites.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.ApplicationIsolationByRoamingUser
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by user and then by application evidence. Storage will roam if Windows user data roaming is enabled. This provides a data store for the application that is accessible in any domain context. The per-application data compartment requires additional trust because it potentially provides a "tunnel" between applications that could compromise the data isolation of applications in particular Web sites.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.ApplicationIsolationByUser
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by user and then by application. Storage is also isolated by computer. This provides a data store for the application that is accessible in any domain context. The per-application data compartment requires additional trust because it potentially provides a "tunnel" between applications that could compromise the data isolation of applications in particular Web sites.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.AssemblyIsolationByMachine
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by computer and then by code assembly. This provides a data store for the assembly that is accessible in any domain context. The per-assembly data compartment requires additional trust because it potentially provides a "tunnel" between applications that could compromise the data isolation of applications in particular Web sites.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.AssemblyIsolationByRoamingUser
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by user and then by assembly evidence. Storage will roam if Windows user data roaming is enabled. This provides a data store for the assembly that is accessible in any domain context. The per-assembly data compartment requires additional trust because it potentially provides a "tunnel" between applications that could compromise the data isolation of applications in particular Web sites.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.AssemblyIsolationByUser
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by user and then by code assembly. Storage is also isolated by computer. This provides a data store for the assembly that is accessible in any domain context. The per-assembly data compartment requires additional trust because it potentially provides a "tunnel" between applications that could compromise the data isolation of applications in particular Web sites.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.DomainIsolationByMachine
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by computer and then by domain and assembly. Data can only be accessed within the context of the same application and only when run on the same computer. This is helpful when a third-party assembly wants to keep a private data store.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.DomainIsolationByRoamingUser
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by user and then by domain and assembly. Storage will roam if Windows user data roaming is enabled. Data can only be accessed within the context of the same application and only when run by the same user. This is helpful when a third-party assembly wants to keep a private data store.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.DomainIsolationByUser
member.summary: Storage is isolated first by user and then by domain and assembly. Storage is also isolated by computer. Data can only be accessed within the context of the same application and only when run by the same user. This is helpful when a third-party assembly wants to keep a private data store.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.None
member.summary: Use of isolated storage is not allowed.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.IsolatedStorageContainment.UnrestrictedIsolatedStorage
member.summary: Use of isolated storage is allowed without restriction. Code has full access to any part of the user store, regardless of the identity of the domain or assembly. This use of isolated storage includes the ability to enumerate the contents of the isolated storage data store.

member.name: T:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags
member.summary: Specifies the type of key container access allowed.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.AllFlags
member.summary: Create, decrypt, delete, and open a key container; export and import a key; sign files using a key; and view and change the access control list for a key container.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.ChangeAcl
member.summary: Change the access control list (ACL) for a key container.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.Create
member.summary: Create a key container. Creating a key container also creates a file on disk. It is very important that any key container that is created is removed when it is no longer in use.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.Decrypt
member.summary: Decrypt a key container. Decryption is a privileged operation because it uses the private key.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.Delete
member.summary: Delete a key container. Deleting a key container can constitute a denial of service attack because it prevents the use of files encrypted or signed with the key. Therefore, deletion is a privileged operation.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.Export
member.summary: Export a key from a key container. The ability to export a key is potentially harmful because it removes the exclusivity of the key.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.Import
member.summary: Import a key into a key container.The ability to import a key can be as harmful as the ability to delete a container because importing a key into a named key container replaces the existing key.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: No access to a key container.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.Open
member.summary:
Open a key container and use the public key.
does not give permission to sign or decrypt files using the private key, but it does allow a user to verify file signatures and to encrypt files. Only the owner of the key is able to decrypt these files using the private key.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.Sign
member.summary: Sign a file using a key. The ability to sign a file is potentially harmful because it can allow a user to sign a file using another user's key.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.KeyContainerPermissionFlags.ViewAcl
member.summary: View the access control list (ACL) for a key container.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.ReflectionPermissionFlag.RestrictedMemberAccess
member.summary: Restricted member access is provided for partially trusted code. Partially trusted code can access nonpublic types and members, but only if the grant set of the partially trusted code includes all permissions in the grant set of the assembly that contains the nonpublic types and members being accessed. This flag is new in the .NET Framework 2.0 SP1.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.ReflectionPermissionFlag.TypeInformation
member.summary: This flag is obsolete. No flags are necessary to enumerate types and members and to examine their metadata. Use instead.

member.summary: The ability to add a certificate to a store. For security reasons, this ability should be granted only to highly trusted code.

member.summary: The ability to perform all certificate and store operations.

member.summary: The ability to create a new store. New stores are created by calling the method.

member.summary: The ability to delete a store. This functionality is not exposed by the class.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.StorePermissionFlags.EnumerateCertificates
member.summary: The ability to enumerate the certificates in a store. For privacy reasons, this ability should be granted only to fully trusted code.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.StorePermissionFlags.EnumerateStores
member.summary: The ability to enumerate the stores on a computer. This functionality is not exposed by the class.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.StorePermissionFlags.NoFlags
member.summary: Permission is not given to perform any certificate or store operations.

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.StorePermissionFlags.OpenStore
member.summary: The ability to open a store. The ability to open a store does not include the ability to enumerate certificates (which raises privacy concerns) or to add or remove certificates (which raises security concerns).

member.name: F:System.Security.Permissions.StorePermissionFlags.RemoveFromStore
member.summary: The ability to remove a certificate from a store. This ability should be granted only to highly trusted code because removing a certificate can result in a denial of service.

member.summary: No zone is specified.

member.name: F:System.Security.SecurityZone.Trusted
member.summary: The trusted sites zone is used for content located on Web sites considered more reputable or trustworthy than other sites on the Internet. Users can use this zone to assign a higher trust level to these sites to minimize the number of authentication requests. The URLs of these trusted Web sites need to be mapped into this zone by the user.

member.name: F:System.Security.SecurityZone.Untrusted
member.summary: The restricted sites zone is used for Web sites with content that could cause, or could have caused, problems when downloaded. The URLs of these untrusted Web sites need to be mapped into this zone by the user.

member.name: T:System.Web.AspNetHostingPermissionLevel
member.summary: Specifies the trust level that is granted to an ASP.NET Web application.

member.name: F:System.Web.AspNetHostingPermissionLevel.High
member.summary: Indicates that features protected with a demand for any level less than or equal to the trust level will succeed. This level is intended for highly trusted managed-code applications that need to use most of the managed permissions that support semi-trusted access. It does not grant some of the highest permissions (for example, the ability to call into native code), but it does provide a way to run trusted applications with least privilege or to provide some level of constraints for highly trusted applications. This level is granted by configuring at least the trust level in the trust section in a configuration file.

member.name: F:System.Web.AspNetHostingPermissionLevel.Low
member.summary: Indicates that features protected with a demand for any level less than or equal to the level will succeed. This level is intended to allow read-only access to limited resources in a constrained environment. This level is granted by specifying the trust level in the trust section in a configuration file.

member.name: F:System.Web.AspNetHostingPermissionLevel.Medium
member.summary: Indicates that features protected with a demand for any level less than or equal to the level will succeed. This level is granted by configuring at least the trust level in the trust section in a configuration file.

member.name: F:System.Web.AspNetHostingPermissionLevel.Minimal
member.summary: Indicates that features protected with a demand for the level will succeed. This level allows code to execute but not to interact with resources present on the system. This level is granted by configuring at least the trust level using the trust section in a configuration file.

member.name: F:System.Web.AspNetHostingPermissionLevel.None
member.summary: Indicates that no permission is granted. All demands for will fail.

member.name: F:System.Web.AspNetHostingPermissionLevel.Unrestricted
member.summary: Indicates that all demands for permission to use all features of an application will be granted. This is equivalent to granting trust level in the trust section in a configuration file.
